newsitem.title: CHINA: China to curb loss of state property to foreigners.
newsitem.headline: China to curb loss of state property to foreigners.

text.p: China called on Sunday for vigilance to control the alarming flow of state-owned property to foreigners.
"Foreign investment is not a free lunch," the official China Daily Business Weekly quoted Tang Zongkun of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences as saying.
"Blind pursuit of foreign investment without consideration of cost would merely relieve the current fund shortage instead of solving enterprises' fundamental difficulties," it said.
Rules should be drawn up immediately to govern deals with foreign investors that concerned property rights, Tang said.
Current regulations had failed to respond to new trends in investment, prompting alarming losses of state-owned property during transactions with overseas investors, he said.
Some regions competed with each other to woo overseas investors, benefiting only the foreigners, he said.

By the end of 1995, foreigners had invested a total of $135.4 billion in 120,000 enterprises in China that employed 120,000 people, the newspaper said. Many of the companies taken over by foreigners were loss-making state firms.
China has grown increasingly concerned in recent years at the loss of state property, the legal ownership and control of which is often only hazily defined.

China's National Administrative Bureau of State-owned Properties was speeding up efforts to develop rules to standardise the treatment of state property in foreign investment deals, the newspaper said but gave no details.
